content.title: Speak to an Ask Eve Nurse
content.content:
About us

About usWhat we do
Meet Team Eve
Annual reports and accounts
Work for Eve
Contact us

Ask Eve is our free and confidential nurse information service.

To contact Ask Eve, call us on 0808 802 0019 – free to call from landlines and mobile phones – or email nurse@eveappeal.org.uk, or you can fill in our contact form and we will get back to you.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Speak to an Ask Eve Nurse

content.title: Speak to an Ask Eve Nurse
content.content:
One of our nurses will get back to you within 48 hours (Monday-Friday).

You can contact Ask Eve and chat to our nurses, Helen and Tracie, about any questions or worries you have about your gynaecological health, from signs and symptoms, HPV, cervical screening, family history or any of the five gynaecological cancers.

There is no question too big, too small or too embarrassing. Ask Eve will be here for you.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Speak to an Ask Eve Nurse

content.title: Speak to an Ask Eve Nurse
content.content:
You can talk to Helen and Tracie in your preferred language as we have an interpretation service available, in over 250 languages, on email or live on the phone.

If you would like to know more about what and how we store your personal information, and who to contact in regards to your personal data please view our Privacy Policy.

We have lots of information on the five gynaecological cancers. This includes their signs and symptoms, risk factors, how they are diagnosed and how they are treated.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Speak to an Ask Eve Nurse

content.title: Speak to an Ask Eve Nurse
content.content:
Sign up to receive emails and get the latest news from The Eve Appeal.

You can view our privacy policy here.

content.title: Screening four cancers (FORECEE)
content.content:
About us

About usWhat we do
Meet Team Eve
Annual reports and accounts
Work for Eve
Contact us

University College London (UCL)

Professor Martin Widschwendter and his team at University College London (UCL) and the FORCEE team developed a new test, the WID-Test to detect and predict the risk of four key cancers that affect women and people with gynae organs.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Screening four cancers (FORECEE)

content.title: Screening four cancers (FORECEE)
content.content:
The first results showed that the test was able to detect up to 30% more women with breast and ovarian cancer than current genetic-based tests.

The WID-Test works by looking at the DNA Methylation of cells taken from a cervical screening sample. DNA methylation sits on top of the DNA and tells the cell which DNA to read and action, it’s like the software of our cells if the DNA is the hardware. DNA methylation is altered by lifestyle factors like diet, hormones and smoking.

The WID-Test doesn’t just detect cancers. The test also looks at how each individual responds to their environment and lifestyle factors, which can also impact the risk of developing cancer in the future.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Screening four cancers (FORECEE)

content.title: Screening four cancers (FORECEE)
content.content:
By bringing these two factors together, the researchers are aiming to develop a screening programme that predicts the risk of these four cancers and enables women and people with gynae organs to take steps to help prevent cancer from developing.

Breast, womb, ovarian and cervical cancers account for more than half of all cancers in women in Europe, that’s around 250,000 people diagnosed with these cancers each year in Europe alone, and almost 45,000 die from them.

The WID-Test could change the future of cancer screening practices. By looking at genetics, lifestyle and environment, this allows a full view of future risk of developing these four key cancers, from just one cervical screening sample.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Screening four cancers (FORECEE)

content.title: Screening four cancers (FORECEE)
content.content:
The next stage in the FORECEE programme is to take the WID-Test into large-scale population trial. This will help find out who the screening test could benefit. For example, all women and people with gynae organs, or just those known to be at a higher risk (e.g. those with a BRCA alteration).

The WID-test has also been utilised to detect womb cancer, called the WID-easy. The WID-easy test has been awarded £2M for a clinical trial across four hospitals in London from the National Institute of Health and Care Research (NIHR).

Read the Nature Comms paper on the breast cancer results
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Screening four cancers (FORECEE)

content.title: Screening four cancers (FORECEE)
content.content:
Read the Nature Comms paper on the ovarian cancer results

Find out more about the progress made in the FORECEE programme.

In this blog, researcher Dr Chiara Herzog goes into detail of how the test works and who it could benefit.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Screening four cancers (FORECEE)

content.title: Screening four cancers (FORECEE)
content.content:
Positive results of the first large-scale clinical trial with the WID-qCIN test have been published in Nature Medicine.

Eve research shows a new method of cervical screening can pick up more women with advanced cell changes than current methods or could predict who would go on to develop advanced cell changes in the next four years.

New research published today in JCO reports a new test which can reliably detect womb cancer from a cervical sample.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Screening four cancers (FORECEE)

content.title: Screening four cancers (FORECEE)
content.content:
Women with fewer protective ‘good’ bacteria in the vagina may be at greater risk of developing ovarian cancer.

content.title: Research
content.content:
About us

About usWhat we do
Meet Team Eve
Annual reports and accounts
Work for Eve
Contact us

Our aim is to prevent gynae cancers from developing in the first place, but if they do develop, we want to make sure they’re detected early so more people survive their diagnosis.

In the UK, gynaecological cancers receive just 5% of cancer research funding (CRUK, 2021).
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Research

content.title: Research
content.content:
Eve is committed to bridging this gap.

We partner with leading researchers and universities in the UK and beyond who share our ambition of a world where all gynaecological cancers are prevented or detected at an early stage.

We fund world-class research from leaders in the field of gynae cancer, as well as support the next generation of researchers. Building up a strong community of scientists, now and for the future, all dedicated to preventing or earlier detecting gynaecological cancers.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Research

content.title: Research
content.content:
Thanks to the generosity of all our wonderful supporters, since 2002 we have funded

Read about some of our recent research announcements.

Third Rare Gynae Cancer Fund – we have awarded Dr Jason Yap from the University of Birmingham a grant to run a project to try and predict the risk of developing vulval cancer in women with lichen sclerosus.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Research

content.title: Research
content.content:
We are delighted to announce that The Eve Appeal has recruited three new research stars to its Research Advisory Committee- Dr Garth Funston, Professor Raji Ganesan and Professor Anne Lanceley.

Today positive results of the first large-scale clinical trial with the WID-qCIN test have been published in Nature Medicine.

NICE have provided new guidelines around genetic testing and ovarian cancer, so now more people who may be at risk of carrying a cancer-causing gene alteration can get tested.
content.source: The Eve Appeal - Research

content.title: Research
content.content:
New research was published which points towards vapes causing similar changes to cheek cells as smoking.
